The '''death penalty for homosexuality''' has historically been implemented by a number of nations worldwide. It is currently still extant in a fairly small number of countries or parts of countries, all due to [[sharia law]]. Even though the law may allow the death penalty it does not mean that it is carried out. Conversely ''de facto'' death penalties may apply, for example the ''[[The Washington Post|Washington Post]]'' said that in Iraq "The penal code does not expressly prohibit homosexual acts, but people have been killed by militias and sentenced to death by judges citing sharia law."
==Current regimes with the death penalty== * [[Afghanistan]]<ref>{{cite web punished by death |publisher=The Washington Post |date=16 June 2016 |accessdate=25 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web There is legal dispute whether the law of the [[United Arab Emirates]] allows for the death penalty for homosexuality, however [[Amnesty International]] could find no instances of the death penalty.<ref name="WP" />
==Historical==
===Australia=== Australian states and territories inherited British laws relating to homosexuality, and laws passed in nineteenth century colonial parliaments retained the provisions which made homosexual activity a capital crime.<ref name=carbery>{{cite journal |last=Carbery |first=Graham |title=Towards Homosexual Equality in Australian Criminal Law: A Brief History |year=2010 |edition=2nd |issue= |pages= |url=http://www.alga.org.au/files/towardsequality2ed.pdf |publisher=Australian Lesbian and Gay Archives Inc.}}</ref> Over time, various jurisdictions began to reduce the death penalty for sodomy to life imprisonment, with Victoria being the last to remove the death penalty for this crime, in 1949.<ref name=carbery />
===United Kingdom=== From 1533 it was a capital felony for any person to "commit the detestable and abominable vice of buggery with mankind or beast," was repealed and re-enacted several times, until it was reinstated in 1563 remaining unchanged until 1861.<ref name="Colonial">{{Cite journal|url=http://digitalcommons.unl.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1061&context=englishfacpubs|work=Journal of Homosexuality|volume=1|issue=3|date=1976|title=Homosexuals and the Death Penalty in Colonial America|author=Louis Crompton|accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref>
===United States and colonial America=== {{See also|Sodomy laws in the United States}} Colonial America had the laws of the United Kingdom, and the revolutionary states took many of those laws as the basis of their own, in some cases verbatim.<ref name="Colonial" /> The last law where the death penalty was on the statute books was South Carolina, the old British law was repealed until 1873, twelve years after the mother country.<ref name="Colonial" />
The number of times the penalty was carried out is unknown, records support two executions, and a number of more uncertain convections, such as "crimes against nature".<ref name="Colonial" />
